subject: Hannah Storm: Counting Our Blessings
body:

  Home | U.S. | World | Politics | SciTech | Health | Entertainment | Business | Opinion | Sports | Blogs | Interactives | Video 

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 



       May 9, 
      2007


Hi, everybody,

Its a glorious spring day 
      here in New York City. We are 
      finally experiencing the warm weather we've all been 
      waiting for. And, while we had a great time today, we are counting our blessings for 
      the folks in other parts of the country who have been experiencing 
      severe weather conditions like the wildfires in Southern 
      California and the floods in 
      Missouri. 
      
 
A 
      couple of days ago, I interviewed a 
      man and his daughter who had hidden in their basement during a tornado in 
      Kansas and the man told me how proud he was of his daughter 
      because she was not worried about  her own well-being but for that of a neighbor and her 
      young baby. After the storm destroyed their town, they managed to get 
      to their neighbor's house and 
      dig the woman and her little baby out of the rubble. And today, 
      the woman who was rescued was on our show and the thing that we 
      were all laughing at was that the baby was so cute and he kept on 
      grabbing the microphone.  
 
Also 
      today, you'll definitely want to check 
      out Sharyl Attkisson's exclusive 
      interview with Sen. Lindsey Graham. Sen. Graham journeyed with 
      Sen. John McCain to Baghdad a couple of weeks ago and what he kept 
      out of the public eye was that after Sen. McCain left,  he 
      stayed on and served in uniform 
      as Colonel Graham for eight days. Prior to his political career, Sen. 
      Graham served in the Air Force, and in the 
      Guard and Reserves for 25 years. Aside from lending a helping hand to our 
      troops, Sen. Graham learned a much more personal lesson. After spending 
      the day with Navy Commander Philip Murphy-Sweet, who helped build the 
      brand new Green Zone courthouse, Murphy-Sweet was killed the following day by an 
      IED. Murphy-Sweet leaves behind a wife and three young children. Sen. 
      Graham said “ (this was) just a random chance in life that I spent the 
      last day with him. He was killed within 24 hours of when I met him. And I 
      guess the story goes for me that nothing good in Iraq happens without a 
      sacrifice.”  This is an interview that you’ll definitely want to see. 
      
 
On a much lighter note, our 
      man about the house Danny Lipford was in Las Vegas checking 
      out some 
      really cool new products for your home and bath. The one I really 
      liked was the Sweep-Away Cabinet Vacuum. 
       You can store it under your sink and it acts as a central 
      vacuum. We would certainly get a lot of use out of it in my 
      house!
 
Finally, I hope you guys are 
      enjoying "CSI" week on The Early 
      Show.  We’ve been having a great time hanging with the 
      stars of the shows and their guest 
      stars like former tennis great John McEnroe, who plays himself on tonight's "CSI: NY." And Joey 
      Lawrence, whom most remember from his days on “Blossom” 
      and “Dancing with the Stars,” takes 
      on a different role as a serial killer and nemesis of Gary Sinise’s character. Lawrence is also starring on Broadway as Billy Flynn 
      in Chicago. Joey told me today that he had 
      to learn all his dialogue in 
      just 10 days! We’ll have more behind the scenes of "CSI" tomorrow on the show. 
      
 
Also 
      tomorrow, Tori Ritchie and I are back in the 
      kitchen at Williams-Sonoma where we’ll show you how to make a 
      Mother's Day brunch; financial guru Ray Martin tells us about how the "working tax" affects dual-income families and writer 
      Mitch Albom will reveal the person whose memories of mom will win them a 
      Royal Caribbean cruise.
 
Take 
      Care,
 
      
Hannah StormEarlyShow@cbs.com
